facts.text: Civil Appeal No 367 of 1959 was filed as an appeal by special leave

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No 367 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 23, 1957 of the Additional Commissioner Punjab in Revision No. 143 of 1956-57

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 23, 1957. of the Additional Commissioner Punjab, in Revision No. 143 of 1956-57.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by WANCHOO, J. on February 22, 1962

anchor.surface_text: 1962. February 22. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-

facts.text: Appellant made application under s. 14-A read with s. 9 of the Punjab Security of Land Tenures Act, No. X of 1953 for ejectment of the respondent

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave from the order of the Financial Commissioner Punjab in respect of the application made by the appellant under s. 14-A

facts.text: Appellant claimed to be the landowner and respondent was tenant-at-will under him

anchor.surface_text: The appellant claimed that he was the landowner and the respondent was a tenant-at-will under him.

facts.text: Appellant claimed he had less than thirty standard acres and required the land for his own cultivation

anchor.surface_text: He therefore claimed ejectment of the respondent on the ground that he had less than thirty standard acres and required the land for his own cultivation.

facts.text: Assistant Collector held respondent liable to ejectment and allowed the application

anchor.surface_text: The application was filed before the Assistant Collector who held that the respondent was liable to ejectment and allowed the application.

facts.text: Respondent appealed to the Collector who allowed the appeal and dismissed the application holding appellant not a landowner

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon there was an appeal by the respondent to the Collector and it was urged there that only a landowner could dispossess a tenant-at-will under s. 14-A. ... The Collector accepted this contention and held that the appellant was not a land-owner

facts.text: Appellant is a lessee from the owner of the land and his lease comprises a larger area including the land of which the respondent is the tenant

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that the appellant is a lessee from the owner of the land and his lease comprises, a larger area of land including the land of which the respondent is the tenant.

facts.text: Commissioner allowed appellant's appeal and restored the order of ejectment passed by the Assistant Collector

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner held that the position of a lessee was just like a mortgagee with possession and that a lessee was a landowner for all purposes. He therefore allowed the appeal and restored the order

facts.text: Financial Commissioner allowed respondent's revision, set aside Commissioner's order, restored Collector's order dismissing ejectment

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the respondent went in revision to the Financial Commissioner, who held that a mere lessee with only constructive possession as in this case could not be included in the term 'landowner' ... He therefore allowed the revision, set aside the order of the Commissioner

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appellant

anchor.surface_text: This was followed by an application by the appellant to this Court for special leave, which was granted and that is how the matter has come up before us.

facts.text: Appellant is not an allottee or a lessee as defined in clauses b and c of section 2 of the East Punjab Displaced Persons Land Resettlement Act, 1949

anchor.surface_text: It is not in dispute that the appellant is not an allottee or a lessee as defined in cls. b and c . respectively of section 2 of the East Punjab Displaced Persons

facts.text: Appellant is not a mortgagee with possession

anchor.surface_text: It is also not in dispute that the appellant is not a mortgagee with possession.

facts.text: In the copy of the Girdawari entries, the appellant is shown as a tenant, entry being Tekan and others, Gairmaurasian first through Ganeshi Gair Maurasi secondhalf

anchor.surface_text: Incidentally we may add that this conclusion is borne out by the fact that in the copy of the Girdawari entries, the appellant in shown as a tenant, the entry being Tekan

facts.text: Appellant holds land under the owner as lessee and is liable to pay rent equal to the lease money

anchor.surface_text: As a lessee he holds land under another person, namely, the owner of the land from whom he has taken the lease and is liable to pay rent equal to the lease money

facts.text: Court held appellant is a tenant within s. 4(5) of the Punjab Tenancy Act, No. XVI of 1887

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is therefore clearly a tenant within s. 4 5 of the Punjab Tenancy Act.

facts.text: Appellant does not come within the four exceptions to the definition of tenant in s. 4(5) of Punjab Tenancy Act

anchor.surface_text: It is not in dispute that the appellant does not come within the four exceptions mentioned in this subsection.

facts.text: Financial Commissioner held appellant had only constructive possession

anchor.surface_text: who held that a mere lessee with only constructive possession as in this case could not be included

facts.text: Appellant contended before Commissioner that he was a landowner within s. 2(1) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The contention on behalf of the appellant before the Commissioner was that he was a landowner within the meaning of that word in s. 2 1 of the Act

facts.text: Collector urged that only a landowner could dispossess tenant-at-will under s.14-A and appellant was merely landlord

anchor.surface_text: it was urged there that only a landowner could dispossess a tenant-at-will under s. 14-A. and as the appellant was not a landowner but merely a landlord

facts.text: Appellant contended he is in enjoyment of part of the profits of the estate under Punjab Land Revenue Act s.3(2)

anchor.surface_text: The contention on behalf of the -appellant is that he must be held to be a landowner within the meaning of this sub- section as he is in the enjoyment of the part of the profits

The question whether the appellant is a landowner or number depends upon the definition of that term in the Act, which is in these terms- Landowner means a person defined as such in the Punjab land Revenue Act, 1887,  Act XVII of 1887 , and shall include an allottee and lessee as defined in clauses  b  and  c . respectively of section 2 of the East Punjab Displaced Persons  Land Resettlement  Act, 1949,  Act XXXVI of 1949  hereinafter referred to as the Resettlement Act. Explanation-In respect of land mortgaged with possession, the mortgagee shall be deemed to be the landowner.

justification_sets.label: Punjab Land Revenue Act s.3(2) support

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the appellant satisfies this definition of the term tenant in s. 4 (5) . As a lessee he holds land under another person, namely, the owner of the land from whom he has taken the lease and is liable to pay rent equal to the lease money for the land which he has taken on lease to that other person. The appellant is therefore clearly a tenant within s. 4 (5) of the Punjab Tenancy Act. He cannot therefore be a landowner under s. 3 (2) of the Punjab Land Revenue Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is obvious that the last part of the definition on which this argument is based applies to persons who are other than tenants and assignees of land revenue, and so we will have to determine whether the appe- llant is a tenant if he is, he is number a landowner.

We are of opinion that the appellant satisfies this definition of the term tenant in s. 4 (5) . As a lessee he holds land under another person, namely, the owner of the land from whom he has taken the lease and is liable to pay rent equal to the lease money for the land which he has taken on lease to that other person. The appellant is therefore clearly a tenant within s. 4 (5) of the Punjab Tenancy Act. He cannot therefore be a landowner under s. 3 (2) of the Punjab Land Revenue Act.
